aligned.modeling.front_knee_acute(x, y, min_angle=100, side='right')[source]¶

10:”RKnee”, 11:”RAnkle”, 13:”LKnee”, 14:”LAnkle”

aligned.modeling.front_knee_obtuse(x, y, max_angle=75, side='right')[source]¶

10:”RKnee”, 11:”RAnkle”, 13:”LKnee”, 14:”LAnkle”

aligned.modeling.head_front(x, y, max_ratio_diff=0.5, side='right')[source]¶

0:”Nose” 15:”REye” 16:”LEye” 17:”REar” 18:”LEar” Compares distance from left eye to right eye If looking forward eye to eye distance will be larger and closer to ear to ear distance If looking if head is front they will be small, and much smaller than ear to ear distance Divide by length from ear to ear to normalize and account for different distances label 0 - head is front label 1 - head is not facing the front (facing the side)

aligned.modeling.hips_square(x, y, max_slope=0.1)[source]¶

9:”RHip” and 12:”LHip” straight line (square hips) would have a slope of 0 0 - stright 1 - not straight

aligned.modeling.mean_ten_still_frames(pose_df)[source]¶

This function find the ten stillest frames in the pose’s df. It returns the mean for each point

aligned.modeling.shoulders_up(x, y, max_angle=10)[source]¶

1:”Neck”, 2:”RShoulder”, 5:”LShoulder”. looks at line from left shoulder to neck, and line from right shoulder to neck if either are not straight returns 1 if both are flat (slope of 0 or close to 0) returns 1

aligned.modeling.step_too_narrow(x, y, min_ratio=0.61)[source]¶

4:”RWrist”, 7:”LWrist”, 11:”RAnkle”, 14:”LAnkle”. compares arm span to distance between feet if feet are wide enough, the distance between feet will be similar to the distance between arms label - 0 feet are wide enough label - 1 feet are too narrow

aligned.modeling.step_too_wide(x, y, max_ratio=0.9)[source]¶

4:”RWrist”, 7:”LWrist”, 11:”RAnkle”, 14:”LAnkle”. compares arm span to distance between feet if feet are wide enough, the distance between feet will be similar to the distance between arms label - 0 feet are wide enough label - 1 feet are too narrow

aligned.modeling.straight_arms_area(x, y, max_area=40, max_slope=0.07)[source]¶

7:”LWrist” 5: ‘LShoulder’ 4:”RWrist” 2: ‘RShoulder’ 1: ‘Neck’

aligned.modeling.straight_arms_slope(x, y, min_slope=-0.07, max_slope=0.0481)[source]¶

input array of 25 x corridnates and array of 25 y corridinates from openpose (x_y_points(data)) output is slope of the line from one hand to another perfectly straight arms would have a slope of zero. 7:”LWrist” and 4:”RWrist” 0 - straight 1 - not straight returns slope and label

aligned.modeling.straight_torso(x, y, min_slope=9)[source]¶

1:”Neck” and 8:”MidHip” perfect would be a vertial line, so steep/high slope is ideal 0 - straight 1 - not straight returns slope and label

aligned.modeling.torso_backward(x, y, min_slope=0.02)[source]¶

1:”Neck” and 8:”MidHip” perfect would be a vertial line, so steep/high slope is ideal swtiches x and y for easier computation, want reversed slope to be zero if straight for too far forward we see if the slope if larger than the min slope 0 - not too far forward 1 - too far forward returns slope and label

aligned.modeling.torso_forward(x, y, min_slope=-0.2)[source]¶

1:”Neck” and 8:”MidHip” perfect would be a vertial line, so steep/high slope is ideal for too far forward we see if the slope if larger than the min slope 0 - not too far forward 1 - too far forward returns slope and label

aligned.modeling.warrior2_label_csv(pose_df, side='right')[source]¶

takes averages of all rows (2d_points) 1 - needs to be adjusted 0 - good Order for 9 digit labeling: 1. arms 2. front_knee_obtuse 3. front_knee_acute 4. head_sideways 5. hips_angled 6. narrow_step 7. shoulders_up 8. torso_forward 9. torso_backward 10. wide_step

aligned.modeling.x_y_points(data)[source]¶

from array of average of points in a single ‘pose_keypoints_2d’ array finds x and y corridnates and return two lists

aligned.process_openpose_user.df2csv_s3(df, s3_path, s3_path_avi, processed_path, bucket_name='alignedstorage')[source]¶

Convert Pandas dataframe to csv. Upload csv and processed avi to s3. Return dataframe.

aligned.process_openpose_user.process_openpose(path_local)[source]¶

Process local avi file using openpose software. Upload files to s3. Return dataframe of keypoints.

aligned.process_openpose_user.upload_and_delete(local_dir, s3_path, processed_path, s3_path_avi)[source]¶

Convert pose keypoints from individual jsons to single df and upload to s3. Return dataframe of pose keypoints.
